captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Let&#39;s take a moment to appreciate 
all the wonderful things that have

come out of Austria. Don&#39;t say Hitler, 
Yahtz. Oh fine. Arnold Schwarzeneggar,

there&#39;s a good one. Erm. I hear the wine&#39;s good, 
and mostly not poisoned now. And presumably a lot

of people come from there who aren&#39;t Hitler. Some 
of whom recently put out a nice little indie game

called Dungeons of Hitler- I mean Hinterburg, 
which I want to talk about because, shockingly,

I rather enjoyed it. In that nice genuine way 
where you wake up in the morning thinking &quot;Ah,

I&#39;m looking forward to playing more of that 
game today,&quot; as opposed to the usual &quot;Oh boy

more grinding away in the dogshit mines 
for the amusement of the cretins as soon

as I half-heartedly rouse myself with a token 
semi-erect wank like a car wash attendant shaking

the foam off a pink chamois leather.&quot; Dungeons 
of Very Austrian Sounding Name follows Luisa,

a lawyer from Vienna who takes a holiday in one 
of Austria&#39;s lovely picturesque mountain villages,

where she has a very authentic European 
package tour experience: getting dragged

out of bed at 7am every morning to get herded to 
some local heritage site, where gangs of locals

in spooky masks try to hit her with sticks. Or 
maybe that was just my last trip to Stockholm.

In this age where the spectre of coziness hangs 
over indie gaming like a great big magenta

Hindenburg there have been many games that have 
tried to bridge the gap between cozy gaming and

traditional action stuff, usually ending up in 
some unsatisfying inbetween space where zombies

keep nibbling your bum while you&#39;re trying 
to water the carrots. But I think Dungeons of

Hindenburg successfully straddles that particular 
sex swing. The secret sauce is that your time is

strictly regimented in a very characteristically 
Germanic kind of way, or more informatively

a very Persona-y kind of way. Your time is divided 
into slots, in the morning you pick an adventuring

area you want to explore looking for dungeons 
to complete and goblins to bully with sticks,

and then in the afternoon slot you hang around 
town shopping and hanging out with your pals,

building up relationship scores and your 
social stats in order to improve your

ability to bully goblins with sticks. It&#39;s 
that same Persona dual gameplay model where

the two modes are separated but affect 
each other, like a bathroom glory hole

situation with another larger hole to 
the side to accommodate reach-arounds.

So in summary it&#39;s very much like Persona 
except with real-time instead of turn-based

combat. Slightly janky and repetitive real-time 
combat, and I&#39;m not a huge fan of the visual

style because every character&#39;s got this thing 
going on with their upper lip that makes it look

like they&#39;ve all got Poirot moustaches. So I 
have more than a few red marks on Funyuns of

Heisenberg&#39;s balance sheet, but if there&#39;s 
one aspect of it I like above all else,

it&#39;s the premise. A bunch of magic portals appear 
in the country surrounding an Austrian village,

out of which goblins and goblin-adjacent 
monsters start spilling and attacking the locals,

and each one leads to a strange ethereal 
dungeon full of trials of combat prowess

and puzzle-solving intellect. But instead of 
doing the normal, sensible thing that peasant

villages do when these things happen, i.e. enlist 
a wandering hero to save them from the monsters,

the peasants of Hinterburg instead hit upon 
the idea of letting tourists into the dungeons,

and now its entire economy is based around selling 
potions and swords and all the dungeon portals

have wheelchair ramps and difficulty ratings 
on signs like they&#39;re fucking ski slopes.

And I wonder why the villagers in 
Diablo never thought to do this,

I mean, either the demons all get killed by 
adventurers or annoyed to death by influencers,

it&#39;s the most economically savvy move by an 
NPC since the potion brewer discovered high

fructose corn syrup. The setting is remarkably 
well-realised, thanks in part to the range of

characters you meet and can become friends with 
- fellow adventurer tourists, the business-owning

locals who appreciate being able to flog 
overpriced plush kobolds to dickheads, the more

conservative locals who wish there weren&#39;t so many 
dickheads around, and the hipsters complaining

about how the commercialization and inauthenticity 
of the tourist experience is irritating the dick

growing prominently out of their heads. There&#39;s 
a nice dual satire going on of both video game

tropes and tourist trap destinations with a 
subtle underlying environmental message but while

treating a monster-stricken peasant village as a 
relaxing getaway for city folk is the main gag,

the really funny part is that it kinda is. 
Relaxing, I mean. You wake up in the morning,

have breakfast on the veranda, choose a nice 
scenic environment to explore and then work

out all those little workaday frustrations by 
punching a load of goblins in the face so hard

that they&#39;ll have to brush their teeth tomorrow 
by bum-shuffling across a shagpile carpet.

Having said that, the combat&#39;s nothing to write 
home about on an erotic postcard. The dungeons are

very Zelda-esque sequences of challenges themed 
around the bespoke magic spells available in each

region, ranging from sequential lever pulling 
puzzles to snowboarding runs, and the combat is

by far the least interesting part of any of it, 
you enter a room and a fucking curtain comes down

and a bunch of generic black monsters round on you 
for no better reason than to gatekeep people who

didn&#39;t show up with high enough level gear like 
a bunch of weird-smelling thirty year old men

loitering in the hallway outside a wargaming shop. 
Your combat abilities are provided by the usual

law firm, Attack, Parry, and Dodge associates, 
but it&#39;s barely worth putting the effort in to

master it when you&#39;ve also got overpowered super 
attacks and magic attacks, all of which feels like

overkill when you exclusively use it against 
the same ambulatory blobs of Marmite-flavoured

play-doh as always. Only each area&#39;s token boss 
fight is interesting, and in the grand Zelda

tradition these are more puzzle challenges 
about deducing the correct spells to use.

And even then the fights don&#39;t evolve at all. The 
big butterfly lady just keeps blithely descending

into range, never ceasing to be surprised when we 
matter-of-factly pull one of her wings off with

our grapple beam for the fourth time. The nicest 
thing one can say about the combat is that it&#39;s

functional enough for purpose, which is to be 
the thing that you do when you&#39;re not doing the

other thing. You don&#39;t actually have to go into 
a dungeon every day, you can opt to hang out at

a beauty spot to increment your Relaxation 
stat, although that&#39;s a very un-relaxing way

of putting it. And by upping our social stats 
we acquire more opportunities to make friends

and gain the buffs that make the combat less 
of a pain in the Hintern. But the necessity

of all that is questionable. I assumed my goal 
was just to beat the dungeons and was slightly

put out at the end when there were multiple NPCs 
and activities I never needed to interact with

at all. The game&#39;s a lot better if instead 
you assume your goal is to make friends with

everyone and play out their stories. Which does 
smack of making excuses. It&#39;s like saying the

combat actually becomes quite interesting if 
you do it with both index fingers stuck up a

dog&#39;s arse. I shouldn&#39;t have to do that, is the 
point. And the dogs weren&#39;t thrilled, either.
